preposition.description: In the time following (an event or another period of time)
examples: there's only one thing to do after an experience like that
she went out, shutting the door after her
chasing after something you can't have
most of them are after money

preposition.description: Next to and following in order or importance.
examples: in their order of priorities health comes after housing
x comes after y in the series

preposition.description: In allusion to (someone or something with the same or a related name)
examples: they named her Pauline, after Barbara's mother
synonyms: as a mark of respect to

examples: she has asked after Iris's mother

adverb &amp; conjunction.description: During the period of time following (an event)
examples: bath time ended in a flood after the taps were left running
he was sorry in after years

adjective.description: Nearer the stern of a ship.

phrases: I called and told her I couldn't come after all
you are my counselor, after all
Who, after all, had set the standards for good English to which we should all aspire?
Perhaps the house will be granted a touch of her theatrical design flair, after all.
It would have been so easy, after all, simply to leak his name if that's what they wanted.
origin: Old English æfter, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch achter.
